segments.text: stuck to that that in effect we organize our lecture and our instruction ecologically rather than many other places have done.

we can, and deliberately so, but it is in Seattle especially easy because the departments of zoology and of botany have strong marine programs or have faculty with strong marine interests so that we don't have to teach our students algology for oceanographers or invertebrates for oceanographers.
So we send them to the basic sciences and let them pick it up there and we can afford them to talk about the ocean

as inhabited for marine organisms talk about benthos or plankton I began to lecture on the upper division level about general biological oceanography along the lines I had indicated earlier along the lines of my training although the first time around or the first one and a half times around I think it was still three quarters or so biology of marine organisms but

Since then, it was biological oceanography proper, with strong emphasis on production biology, very little on zoogeography, or biogeography, which I consider to be another legitimate part of biological oceanography, but I didn't know much about it, so it was primarily production biology.
And I lectured to biologists and non-biologists, that is, biological oceanographers and non-biological oceanographers, who in those years all were sitting through the same courses.
And these upper division lectures were prescribed in our undergraduate curriculum, but all graduate students who came from the outside had to take them, too.
So it was a very mixed audience.

The biologists in those years often accused me of that I really did not address them, but I was addressing the other ones, the non-biologists, because I treated life in the ocean, which they had come to study, I treated life in the ocean strictly in terms of carbon or chlorophyll and so on, which is very easy then for physical and say chemical oceanographers to understand, but not very

not firing up the imagination of the biologists but this emphasis was not really to please the non-biologists or to make it easy for them but it was really my way of outlook that I thought that in terms of chlorophyll you can compare the North Pacific with the North Atlantic or the North Pacific
in the temperate North Pacific with the tropical North Pacific.
Whereas if you had species lists, well, you couldn't really.
So it was designed.
But many bollushes were very unhappy and still are.
But that is just my way of looking at the world.
At that time, I thought already of writing it up, writing a textbook.

The lecture notes, at least, were organized such that they were proper referencing where did I get this idea from and where did that slide come from, because there was no book which treated the ocean.
There was no book on biological oceanography.
The oceans were way outdated already then.
I think they were outdated when they were written, as far as biology is concerned.
Otherwise, a very good book, but in biology, quite so so.
Well, I will come back to that book later.
I didn't get to it yet.
I did draw early on the results of model studies, of theoretical studies in biological oceanography, which also was done rarely in those years.
But because I was not trained mathematically enough, I could not really teach by means of models, which would be the most elegant way.
Nobody did it in those years except Reilly himself.
But at least I used the results and said, look, students, that is the future.
And again, until very recently, until Parsons' textbook came about, there was no text on which you could draw.
As far as research is concerned, I emphasize plankton methods.
I continue to be interested in methods, and especially of the assessment of phytoplankton standing stock.
That is the inheritance from cry.
I was a little disenchanted with the chemical method, but I also did not want to have
phytoplankton theses and phytoplankton written which just had long species lists.
So in the first years, very much on my mind was the problem of how to convert from species lists into mass estimates.
And the theses by Lawrence, for example, and by Hobson, the master theses by both, and also by Strathman were very much concerned with those issues.

In a way, I did not continue with zooplankton work, and the reason is that in 1961, there was a symposium held in Copenhagen on zooplankton, which was to be the successor to that mentioned 1957 symposium on primal production.
The zooplankton symposium was not nearly as good as the phytoplankton symposium, but that's besides the point.

I was invited, no, I think I contributed a paper on the role of the small zooplankton, which nobody on this continent at that time talked about, which is again bringing up, reminding the people of the Lohmann idea.
I just reviewed literature and said, now look, there are many, many organisms which slip through the meshes you use.
and I was invited to give a review on the vertical distribution of soroplankton, which I did, but that was not well done in my opinion, so I
rewrote it and re-expanded it and finished that in 1963 and that was published in 1964.
And in that review, of course I reviewed among other things the vertical migration issue, pointing out that very often organisms don't migrate, which I had mentioned before.
But I also elaborated on, or I touched upon, the problem of the vertical distribution of very small zooplankton, say CLJs and nauplii, in the mixed layer.
and

When I finished that review, I thought the only really interesting aspect in zooplankton work, besides biogeography, which is a different issue, but otherwise the only really important issue before us is this question of the zooplankton as a mixed layer, which ties into production studies, and I can't go into this.
The upshot as far as my own scientific future is concerned was that I realized that I couldn't do it myself.
First, it involved revisiting of populations, which is objectively difficult to come back to the same population in the open sea.
It can't be done even now.
But the other issue is of the statistical problems.

to which I can't go into either, but at any rate I realized that I didn't have the equipment, training-wise, nor the logistics behind me, and so I just left it at that, and it is only beginning to be picked up now.
Well, people begin to think about along these lines now.
But I was so discouraged that I just left zooplankton work, distribution work, and have never done it ever since, although, of course, I still lecture about it.
the, what shall I say, I was to say major accomplishment, but that is a little too much.
What I had to do here is teach oceanography, of course, and get biological oceanography and get the research going.
And what I realized very early was that the teaching of biological oceanography, whatever there was, was directed at the open ocean entirely, that biological oceanography or the

interaction of life with the sea was treated as if there was no bottom but of course it is obvious and was obvious then that much of the research amid much of the interaction between man and the sea and much of the research our students would have to do would be concerned with the ocean on the shelf and on the shelf of course you can't neglect the seabed
So I began to introduce benthic teaching, teaching on the benthos, and also to bring in, to build up a research effort.
The research effort was in part
In expansion of the Plumpton work, I wanted to try to apply chemical methods, quick methods, to an assessment of the overall activity of the community and the overall concentration.
And out of this attempt came Pramatma's work, who is one of my best students, I think.
Very much independent, but still my student.
He introduced the determination of oxygen consumption by the seabed.
It had been invented by somebody else, but he really made a golden proposition out of it.

We realized, of course, that we could not, this is early 1960s now, we realized that we would have to work on the organisms too, and so I looked around for money to take up classical benthic quantitative work and invited, advertised for it, and we invited a Norwegian, Mr. Lee, to come here.
And Lee then very, who was originally a plantologist but learned
the literature very, very quickly and again was very independent, but in effect he started our Benthic work here and then very quickly got ahead of

many other concurrent workers by introducing methods in plant sociology into well-developed mathematical methods into the marine domain, and therefore advanced the field very much beyond what was done by the Danish school, which dominated the east coast of this country until ten years later almost.
Lee, if I remember correctly, came in late 1962.
For Lee, I identified the polychaetes.

I sort of, I agreed to identify the polychaetes because, of course, that's always an issue now if you take these many samples, who is going to identify, recognize the species, and then count them before you can start thinking about them.
And Lee took the Causatians and a colleague of...
a professional, Mr. Kiska, took the bivalves and the cannadomes, and there were a few others helping in the minor groups.
I said, well, sure, I take the polykids because I knew them.
I also had looked at a few samples here, and uninhabited, in sand,
where usually you find new species.
If you want to find new species, that was the lesson learned in Kiel by Remane, look at clean sand and you will find just one species after another.
And so I had done here just to find out how well known is this region, using the clean sand as sort of the yardstick.
If many species were unknown, then who knows what kind of surprises would wait on Markbottom, say.

I took a few samples, two I believe, and there was only one new species and so I was quite relaxed and certainly sure I can identify for using polychaetes, of course through research assistance students.
It turned out that was a great mistake.
The polychaete fauna wasn't well known and in the years since then, since 1962 or 3, we have added all
The polycate found 170% of what it was when we started out.
And in effect, I have been trapped since then in identifying polycates.
Not identifying, but describing polycates, making revisions, and writing keys.
together with one of my students.
And I'm just now in the process of winding that up.
I hope in another year I will finish this second volume to the polykids of British Columbia and Washington.
That's a natural unit.
And then get rid of it because the initial excitement has worn off, which always it does.
But more importantly,
In an oceanography department, this is a little out of place.
Of course, biological oceanographers have to know organisms.
Otherwise, if they don't tack on the name or pin on the name to the organisms, they can't use the literature because the name only opens to the literature.
But to spend much time on working
on the taxonomy, that is really what the ologists are being paid for.
And the disadvantage then is that I do the logical work here, which is fine, nobody is against it, but I can't train students in it.

Because if I say, where to train poly-kid students in oceanography, they still would have to take all the physical courses and all the chemical oceanography and what have you, and in consequence wouldn't have enough knowledge of entomology and of physiology and what have you.
And so they would not be really competitive.
Which jobs would they take?
They would not be full zoologists, but they wouldn't be full oceanographers either.

I think it's not good for my role as a teacher to continue to work on the polygates, even if I enjoyed it, which I don't anymore, because keys are just tools, very important tools, but you never get them in a textbook, you never become famous, because you just sharpen tools for the others.
And so when I'm through these keys, I will not regret it.
As I said, very important, but I don't say anything about the ocean.
So that was really a trap into which I got half of my papers now on polychaetes, not about the ocean or plankton methods at all.
Now, to finish this treatment of what we did in the Bentos, we added, of course, a Bentos faculty, but on a faculty, teaching faculty, so that I didn't have to lecture about it.
But again, we had somebody who didn't stick to it, who didn't publish.
That happens, of course.
And because of the funding problems for and for Lee, who were on soft money,
We just couldn't keep them here because they were receiving offers all the time and said, well, if you people can't give me a tenured position, well, I will just leave.
And so they did.
And after Parmakmat left, who was the last one, in 72 or 73, the whole Bento's effort was really for naught.
We had been on the map for a while, but that was it.
People still write here and want to study Bentos, but of course that is for reasons of publications done ten years ago.
And if now somebody speaks about theater, work on Bentos, he usually means, or she usually means Paine's work in the zoology department, which has, or who, Paine rather, who
since the mid-60s has really developed new ideas which have fertilized, so to speak, ecology in general, not just marine work, but ecology in general.
And that is why one ought to come here to study Inventor's work.

Although I must make him a qualifier, now we have hired somebody new a year ago, Peter, or two years ago, Peter Jumas, who is this young generation, first of all, he's very good, but also this young generation where the training is so much better that all the time I'm just embarrassed in talking to him, which happens to all older people, I suppose, that the younger generation is better trained, and the only...

handicap they have is that they don't have enough experience that I know just by experience what the answer is whereas they have to derive it and it takes them half a minute for the derivation but once they have the experience of course we are the old people are just old well
So my work in Bentos, in a way, has not been too successful because of these institutional restraints or accidents, if you want to put it this way, that you hire somebody and he doesn't pan out.
That was through the 60s.
During the mid-60s, I began to become interested in national ocean politics.
I was, from 1964 to 1970, the biologist on NASCO, the Academy Committee on Oceanography, about which I don't have to tell you anything, I suppose.
I was the successor of Dixie Lee Ray, who now is our governor.
And I also participated in those years on other committees, on national levels, visiting committees and advisory boards and what have you, and also was active in university self-governance here.
It was only a sort of temporary love affair.
After a few years, during which I learned very, very much.
These were very interesting years.
After a few years, I began to become disenchanted, perhaps through my own development, further development, but also because NASCO,
was not longer a very effective speaker in the late 60s on the national stage.
There were so many others now speaking for oceanography, and, of course, owing to the war, the general national scene was slightly confused, to put it mildly.
So it wasn't very interesting anymore, and Nazgul only had to speak, address politics, question, kill brush fires here and there.
There was no science anymore.
So when they were dissolved under Calhoun's leadership,
Calhoun saw to it that it was restructured, and I was glad to be rotated off.
And I guess it had to do with my development, too.
Since those years, I have sort of withdrawn.
I've withdrawn a little too strong, but I'm not so long as interested in working on this committee and that university panel.

which in part is my own development, but many other colleagues after the Vietnam experience, on this campus at least, have withdrawn and are not longer so active helping to run the university, but just leave it to the president or administrators to the dean.
So in a way, I'm a child of my age, of course, and that I have, in other words, I have returned to research and teaching.
I certainly am not interested in administration as a profession, although I see the virtue and the challenge to it.
But right now, I'm still an active scientist.
And of course, 10 years later, who knows?
But during the 60s, I had the choice several times to become largely the administrator.
And I said, no.
And still, 10 years later, I don't regret it.
But as I said, another 10 years, who knows?
So what is really left now is to say what kind of research I have done in the 70s.
Part of the research, half of the papers is polykids, as I mentioned, and I hope to wind it up soon.
I do have the textbook still on my mind, and I will come back to this later.
There was the...

Let me say that I mentioned that symposium on primary productivity in 1957, which was the first summary of what was going on, but which also was a milestone and led us on for a few very active years in primary productivity research, which was all done by chemical methods.
Carbon-14, in a way, is a chemical method.

chlorophyll is a chemical method, nobody looked through the microscope anymore, but by 1965 or so the cream was off, sort of, and many people, including me, thought that the demise is inside and so get off and do something better, and I got into the force by the circumstances, got into the bentos, more or less.

And for others it appeared clear, and I agreed at that time, that secondary production, animal production, would now be the most important theme, which would, of course, bring us back to zooplankton, but it was

not so much so plant and distribution, but it was clear that we would have to do very much work in the lab on grazing rates, on growth rates, and so on and so forth, which several people then did, but I didn't join because it didn't interest me so much.
But that was in the mid-60s what seemed to be the important part, and I tried to push it on the national level, too, and secondary product on the bottom.
get away from just counting animals but say now what do they do, how fast do they grow, what do they do to each other.
What do they do to each other is what pain is doing and I try to push now how fast is it being done.
And what does a mud bottom do to the overlying sea water in contrast to a sand bottom?
What's the difference between sand and mud bottom when you view it from above, from the water?
Is there any difference?
So these kinds of issues of secondary production I thought would be interesting, but I largely talked about it without doing very much.
It turned out then that the assessment of the primary production of that demise was not quite right.
Primarily under Dugdale's leadership, the field has been reopened and is now really moving again.
We realized, and Dugdale has done that before he came here, but he was, Dugdale was here for quite a while, and you ought to talk to Dugdale, really, history of oceanography in Maine.
You might want to note that down.
Duckdale put modern plant physiology together with what we have done so before.
What he tried to do, and still is, to predict plant growth from, that is, a rate, from the nutrient concentrations, which we had looked at in a far too simple-minded way before.
And it turned out that this involves a lot of lab work, which is still going on, but also very much more sophisticated sampling at sea.

So that he built up here, and I'm sorry, he also pointed out and did do something about it, that more mathematical modeling is needed, which he didn't invent, but he tried to build up a group where everything was done at the same time.
So there was a lot of interaction about it.
But I guess because of different temperaments, I think that's the principal reason, but also because of the way we are spread through different buildings.
We really never cooperated.

This building did its thing, and Duckdale and the other building did his thing, and they had different coffee pots, met every day, and when the interests diverged, went on different expeditions, so we developed really in a different manner.

so much that when people here on this floor looked for mathematicians and hired a very good mathematician, Winter, to work on productivity data, local productivity data in Puget Sound, whereas Duckville never looked at local water.
They always had thought of subtropical regions for good reasons.
So when we hired this new man, even our modeling approach was different from theirs.
So there were really two modeling groups in Seattle, which must have looked very strange to the outside.
But that is the way it went.
Different traditions within the same place, which is a function of size and script that happens, too, that people don't know what Miller does in the other one.
Because they never eat with each other.
One has his lunch group, the other one this one.
So in a way, we were a...
victim of size.

At any rate, by introducing Winter into the field, he taught in the first year primarily to me, I learned a great deal about modeling and what good it can do, which reinforced my youth really, but I also came back to primary production in a way.

and also realized that what was missing in oceanography to really make the big next step after the introduction of the carbon-14 method was, yes, all right, more secondary production, but more importantly, to have more theory.

Not to have more expedition, more data, and El Said in Texas A&M is the one who says we need more data and continues to go to the Antarctic Ocean, which I very much admire because it's an awful place to go.
But I think, in my opinion, that is an opinion, we need more theory.
into which to fit new data.
There are enough data laying around to construct theory and then try to test the theory or discard or substantiate it, rather than to continue to take observations at sea.
That is what I learned from Winter, among other things.
So in a way, then, we are again back to primary production, in a way, but we don't do it very actively.
Winter was hired in 1970, and the big paper came out in 74, the big paper on Puget Sound.
And in the meantime, we have another paper in press.
But this development was interrupted by a sabbatical, which I spent at Scripps in, yeah, now I don't know, 71 to 72, I guess so.
Or 72 to 73, I don't recall.
At any rate, I went there not only to have the sabbatical, but to write the textbook.
But because I didn't know how to spend a sabbatical, I didn't manage quite.

The mistake I made was that I had an obligation here to finish an article with a co-author, and there was another manuscript which was almost ready and had been sitting on my desk for a year, and when I came to Scripps and for the first time had time to think about it leisurely without all the time somebody coming in or hurrying away to lectures, I saw how bad it was.
There was a month gone for this and for that.
So I really wrote only for two or three months.
Now I know how to write it, and I also know that I have to restrict my scope considerably.
Originally, I wanted to write a textbook for biological oceanography.
All of it.
And there is no book yet which does it.
Although there are a few multi-author books, it is still not a book you can use in class.
